text: hi everyone anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new deer hunter
lp monomania deer hunter is a
georgia-based rock band this is their
full-length release and they've pretty
much been one of the bigger names in
indie rock for the past five or so years
and their style tends to lean toward the
more psychedelic side of things noise
pop dream pop as well as a little bit of
shoegaze the band's earlier releases
were very much sonic explorations
through
rock music whereas on their later
releases they would flex their pop
sensibilities through the songwriting of
locket punt and bradford cox with albums
like
microcastle as well as the very well
produced and instrumentally lavish
halcyon digest with the direction that
the band was going and you would think
that they were just one album away from
making some kind of big indie crossover
into the mainstream where you have this
underground band and slowly over time
they gain more pop appeal and then they
sort of you know get that sliver of
limelight from more general music
listeners given the material that was on
halcyon digest the last album they came
out with and how high that album charted
on the billboard charts i thought that
deer hunter would be capable of making
an album that had a lot of pop appeal
even more pop appeal but still maintain
their personality but deer hunter is
nothing if not full of surprises and it
seems that the band has completely
turned around on this new album and have
gone back to their noisier roots on this
album deer hunter dishes out a lot of
rock tunes with a strong garage rock
attitude and tracks that are really sort
of straightforward and just get right to
the point not so much the more
psychedelic and spaced out jams that
were inhabiting an album like
cryptograms so it's not like monomania
is a return to form or anything in a way
monomania is most definitely progression
you could say that over time deer hunter
has been working to kind of eliminate
from their musical formula and monomania
in its own sort of way does that by
getting rid of very lavish detailed
layered psychedelic production in favor
of a recording that sounds more like it
was recorded very shoddily in a bedroom
if anything a lot of songs on this album
kind of feel like some of the more
straightforward material to come out of
bradford cox solo project atlas sound
but in this instance way more lively
instrumentally and a little punchier in
a way this new album actually kind of
has the guts that i wish bradford cox's
last full-length lp did the very rough
aesthetic that deer hunter goes for on
this lp definitely makes a lot of these
songs stick out bradford cox's vocals
are mixed very high smothering
almost all of the instrumentation
underneath his voice the guitars are
pretty distorted and when they're not
distorted they're just very clear sharp
and up front the drums are very dirty
gritty the more subtle tracks on this lp
come off very catchy and clear as well
but newer fans to deer hunter who are
really huge into albums like microcastle
as well as halcyon digest may see songs
like this as as possibly being just a
little overly simple for sure the
direction that deer hunter goes in on
this lp does have appeal it's helped the
careers of many garage rockers over the
years neo garage rockers like jay [ __ ]
as well as ty siegel but what's really
going to make this album stick with
people is whether or not the songs are
memorable if they're catchy if they're
passionate the band starts this lp
pretty eccentric with the song neon
junkyard which is this tune that
features a pretty captivating vocal
melody sharp guitar leads bradford cox
on certain parts of the song makes these
really weird mouth noises
that echo out into oblivion just kind of
adding a psychedelic characteristic to
this song the song has a pretty basic
structure but that doesn't necessarily
ruin it because the melodies are so
sharp what sort of ends up being a
downside to the tune is that at the very
end when it seems like the band gets
kind of tired of building the song one
piece after another they just sort of
embark upon this very static
underwhelming noisy jam until the song
just sort of peters out this is
something deer hunter does on quite a
few tracks from this lp actually and
sometimes it just feels sort of boring
in other times like for example the song
monomania the title track on this lp it
comes off as really intense thrilling
and chaotic if there was any question
that deer hunter was going in a garage
rock direction with this album the song
leather jacket clears that up with some
really jagged whaling guitars just an
attitude filled riff i just cannot
stress how much attitude just
plays a freaking role on this album to
the point where it really sort of
overshadows the song sometimes or makes
a really lackluster song seem a little
more interesting than it really is the
track the missing is maybe the first
song on this album that people will
acknowledge as being sort of a
traditional deer hunter song it's more
toned down more subtle the
instrumentation rings through clearly
not much distortion on this thing
bradford cox sings a really sweet vocal
melody and the emotion behind his voice
comes off as is very charismatic yet
sort of emotionally disconnected cool i
like the really warm synthesizers that
come in after the verses on this track
too it adds a really nice touch i think
people will find a lot of appeal in this
song who are long time deer hunter fans
as well as the track dream captain where
bradford cox has some pretty quaint
lyrics on the track that are really sort
of cute and the song sleepwalking too is
a quieter number on this lp that comes
off pretty charming through its
subtleties even if you don't necessarily
love what deer hunter did on this new
album i think that some of the quieter
moments on this lp are worth salvaging
and just sort of you know taking into
consideration in terms of ideas for when
deer hunter does another full length
there are some moments on this album
though where the simplicity doesn't
necessarily work in deer hunter's favor
like the song blue agent which i feel
like in terms of a tune is a fine track
but as the band is performing this song
without introducing new ideas as it goes
along the track just feels really
tedious and the song th m as well and
there are some instances on this album
where some tracks don't even feel like
that like the song pensacola just sounds
like really bad alternative country it's
actually like the band is trying to do
an alternative country parody with these
really hokey guitar leads and very
generic guitar chords and the way
bradford cox is singing on this song
it's really campy way it seems like he's
really kind of yucking it up on what
might be a joke an honestly night bike
toward the end of this lp is another
sort of least favorite of mine where
bradford cox seems to be very
indulgently strumming and singing in
this very directionless way that does
not feel entertaining at all it's at
this point on the album where it feels
like the attitude that toward the
beginning of the lp that felt very
refreshing and kind of badass and
exciting is now getting really tiring
especially given how many tracks on this
lp felt more like posturing than you
know just a good solid song while in
theory i would have been interested in
an album where deer hunter went in a
noisier garage rock direction i mean
that's what i assumed based on the title
track that dropped before this album
which i still love but when it comes to
the practice of putting this album
together it seems like deer hunter left
out some essential details some catchier
songs and really just some more raw
energy i'm feeling a light decent six on
this lp if you've given it a listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it
why
and um
here's another opinion hey listen
cal's going to give it to you straight
i've listened to plenty of deer runner
in my day
and the man mania
rex
i've heard plenty of sayings with guitar
and drums but none of them nice is this
there you go
deer hunter
mono mania
forever
